title: Theodore Roosevelt Statue to Be Removed From American Museum of Natural History
summary: The statue, unveiled in 1940, has long stirred controversy. The statue of Theodore Roosevelt that has stood at the Central Park West entrance of the American Museum of Natural History for decades is to be removed amid renewed criticism that it is racist and glorifies colonialism.

title: Four Things to Watch in Tuesday's New York Primary Elections
summary: This year will see an avalanche of mailed-in ballots, insurgents targeting incumbents, crowded fields and one candidate fighting on two fronts. Tuesday's primary elections in New York will be unprecedented in several ways.

title: China Halts Some Tyson Chicken Shipments Over Covid-19
summary: Tyson on Friday said 481 employees across its northwest Arkansas operations had tested positive for the coronavirus since early June.

title: In France, Police Tactics Are Less Lethal-but Still Stir Controversy
summary: Officers' restraint in Dijon during recent violence draws praise as well as criticism. PARIS-When armed Chechens descended on the provincial city of Dijon this month and occupied a predominantly North African neighborhood, the French police broke up fighting with locals when they could and called in reinforcements-but kept their guns in their holsters.

title: Lockdown States and the Jobless
summary: Job gains are much greater in states that have reopened faster.. The Labor Department on Friday reported jobless rates in May for the 50 states, and the news is the greater than usual variation. Some state economies are recovering much faster than others, and the worst performing tend to be those that have imposed the most severe lockdowns.

title: The New Urban Flight
summary: Riots and the pandemic are driving another exodus from big cities.. New York City begins to open up for office work on Monday, and the news is that most people are staying home. This may be temporary, but there were signs even before the pandemic and riots that the revival of America's cities was going in reverse. This is especially ominous for progressive cities in high-tax states.

title: Failure in the Virtual Classroom
summary: A study finds that many schools barely cared if kids did any work.. The remote-learning experiment isn't going well. This month the University of Washington's Center on Reinventing Public Education published a report looking at how 477 school districts nationwide have responded to the Covid-19 crisis. Its findings reveal widespread neglect of students.

title: White House Preparing for Second Wave of Coronavirus, Trade Adviser Says
summary: 'We are filling the stockpile in anticipation of a possible problem in the fall,' Peter Navarro says. White House trade adviser Peter Navarro said Sunday that the Trump administration is preparing for a second wave of coronavirus infections.

title: 'Fortnite' Removes Police Cars From Game
summary: Change in videogame comes amid national debate over law-enforcement practices. Police cars have been removed from the hit videogame "Fortnite," a change that comes amid a national debate over law-enforcement practices in response to the killing of George Floyd while in Minneapolis police custody.

title: 'On the Road: A Tribute to John Hartford' Review: Loosen Up and Fly Right
summary: A multiflavor roots-music salute to a hero of adventurous genre mixing..

title: The Power of Personal Agency
summary: The idea that only whites can undo 'structural racism' sends young blacks a message of powerlessness.. In the aftermath of George Floyd's killing, a telling scene unfolded at a "Justice Can't Wait" vigil in Bethesda, Md. Nearly 1,000 predominantly white residents-many on their knees with both hands in the air-chanted: "I will love my black neighbors the same as my white ones." These pledges by white allies that black lives matter to them are emerging across the country as the latest expression of performative empathy.

title: Rules for Clinical Trials in a Pandemic
summary: A study out of Britain shows how to learn more, faster about promising coronavirus treatments.. A new study finds that adding a simple steroid to the treatment of severe Covid-19 cases can significantly reduce deaths. That's another milestone in the battle against the virus. It shows a path for reducing Covid deaths faster through medical innovation and for keeping the health-care system from being overwhelmed as the epidemic spreads.

title: Notable & Quotable: Hillsdale's Statement
summary: 'It is not the practice of the College to respond to petitions or other instruments meant to gain an object by pressure. The College operates by reasoned deliberation, study, and thought.'. A June 18 letter from the leaders of Hillsdale College:

title: Bad Economy? Unleash Private Equity
summary: Firms maligned as 'vampires' in fact save jobs and businesses.. About $3 trillion of coronavirus relief approved by Congress helped the economy survive the pandemic, but what happens when the funds run out? With 40 million people out of work, it is time to unleash the power of private equity.

title: 'Apocalypse Never' Review: False Gods for Lost Souls
summary: Environmentalism offers emotional relief and spiritual satisfaction, giving its adherents a sense of purpose and transcendence.. There is a recurring puzzle in the history of the environmental movement: Why do green activists keep promoting policies that are harmful not only to humans but also to the environment? Michael Shellenberger is determined to solve this problem, and he is singularly well qualified.

title: U.K. Counterterrorism Police Investigating Knife Attack That Left Three Dead
summary: Local police say they have arrested a 25-year-old man whom they suspect of murder. A knife attack that left three dead and three others wounded in a town 40 miles west of London is being treated as a terrorist incident, police said on Sunday.

title: Cash Remains King as Companies Close a Dismal Second Quarter
summary: Hilton sold loyalty points. Lennar stopped buying land. America's biggest companies are hoarding cash to ride out the pandemic.. Giant companies from McDonald's Corp. to Intel Corp. are husbanding cash, cutting costs and tapping debt, all moves that bolster their resilience amid persistent uncertainty wrought by the new coronavirus.

title: Fake Countries Have a Hard Time Dealing with the Pandemic, Too
summary: Resume Subscription. If Covid-19 has put the kibosh on your summer travel plans, why not form your own country?

title: Economy Week Ahead: Housing, Factories and Consumer Spending
summary: Data out this week will show where damage from coronavirus is still lingering. Data out this week will show where the economy is starting to mend and where damage is lingering from efforts to contain the new coronavirus.

title: After China Border Fight, India Likely Weighs Closer U.S. Military Ties
summary: South Asian country also is expected to work with Japan, Australia and others to check its neighbor. NEW DELHI-Faced with an increasingly assertive and well-armed China, Indian policy makers are likely considering whether to further expand military cooperation with the U.S. and American allies who share their concerns about Beijing's rising power, according to analysts.

title: Calpers Takes a Bold and Risky Investment Strategy
summary: Ben Meng sketches a two-prong strategy to earn more than stock and bond markets seem likely to provide.. Reading Ben Meng's "Calpers Prepares for the Long Haul" (op-ed, June 15) in the face of the recent bailouts of overleveraged and overrisked companies makes me think that the lunatics are truly running the asylum that our market economy has become. Can a person of his experience and knowledge truly believe that more risk and leverage are the right answers for millions of California retirees at a time when little or no risk is truly priced into markets?

title: Cuba's Shameful Trafficking of Its Doctors
summary: Cuba's overseas medical missions, which generate over half of Cuba's national budget (three times more than tourism), and which the State Department now recognizes as "forced labor.". Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "Cuban Medical Brigades to Mexico" (Americas, June 15) raises the "lack of transparency" with Cuba's overseas medical missions, which generate over half of Cuba's national budget (three times more than tourism), and which the State Department now recognizes as "forced labor."

title: Antonio Gramsci Would Be Thrilled by Today's Politics
summary: Gramsci taught that not bloody Bolshevik terror but the patient process of undermining all institutions of Western culture would ultimately make the revolution succeed.. Mary Anastasia O'Grady deserves gratitude for digging up Antonio Gramsci ("The Culture Wars and the Street Wars," Americas, June 8). It is incomprehensible why his name seems to have vanished into obscurity while his revolutionary strategy triumphed in the past half-century for all to see. Gramsci taught that not bloody Bolshevik terror but the patient process of undermining all institutions of Western culture would ultimately make the revolution succeed. This applies to government, education, churches, marriage and the family. Theologically speaking, this destructive program targets the orders of creation. Christians should be alarmed by Gramscian-style calls to defund or even disband, rather than reform, police departments, because from the Christian perspective, the maintenance of law and order in the secular realm is divinely ordained.

title: As New York City Reopens, Driving Becomes a Tempting Commute
summary: With social distancing nearly impossible on commuter trains and buses, some companies consider subsidizing employees' parking. Parking garages are hoping for a surge in business as tens of thousands of office workers return to Manhattan during New York City's reopening, which is expected to enter its second phase Monday.

title: George Floyd and Derek Chauvin: The Lives of the Victim and His Killer
summary: Resume Subscription. George Floyd and Derek Chauvin grew up on opposite sides of the stark racial divide that cuts through America.

title: Minneapolis Shooting Leaves One Person Dead, 11 Others Wounded
summary: Police said no one was in custody after the shooting in the city's Uptown commercial district, which includes several bars and restaurants.. Minneapolis Police said they are investigating a string of shootings that left one man dead and wounded 11 other people early Sunday morning.

title: More Stocks Drive Rally, Decreasing Reliance on Big Tech
summary: After brief periods of rotating leadership, a wider-ranging group of stocks is rising in lockstep. High-flying technology companies have helped the U.S. stock market claw back most of its losses for the year. Now, other stocks are helping to carry the load.

title: The Berman Resistance
summary: The grandstanding former U.S. Attorney is no political martyr.. So here's the plan. We need to remove a U.S. Attorney because he's investigating associates of the President. Let's wait until four months before the election, and let's do it on a Friday night so it looks suspicious and the guy can refuse to step down and make himself a martyr to the Resistance. Yeah, that'll fool everybody.

title: Trump's Tulsa Rally Draws Smaller-Than-Expected Crowd
summary: President pitches law-and-order message, warning against attacks on 'our values'. TULSA, Okla.-President Trump returned to the campaign stage for the first time since March, pitching a law-and-order message and warning against an attack on "our heritage" as protests over policing and racial injustice continued across the country.

title: A War of Meaningless Words
summary: Terms like 'flatten the curve' and 'defund the police' often mask shifting purposes.. Truth or consequences? "When I use a word," says Lewis Carroll's Humpty Dumpty, "it means just what I choose it to mean-neither more nor less." In other words, anything he wants it to mean. Prescient. Today words are abused and truth has become so debased that no one believes anything anymore.

title: Why the U.S. Is Moving Troops Out of Germany
summary: Forces are needed in the Indo-Pacific. And Berlin should contribute more to European security.. To counter China and Russia, two great-power competitors, U.S. forces must be deployed abroad in a more forward and expeditionary manner than they have been in recent years. This is the main reason the U.S. will reduce its permanently stationed force in Germany from 34,500 troops to 25,000.

title: Barr Scrutinized Over Firing of U.S. Attorney
summary: Mr. Barr's critics accuse him of undermining the Justice Department's tradition of independence. WASHINGTON-Attorney General William Barr has earned a reputation for being so hard-charging within the Justice Department that even his close aides call him "the Buffalo."

summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Tiz the Law Wins Belmont Stakes
summary: Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the first leg of this year's Triple Crown was run in New York for the first time ever. Tiz the Law will go into the record books as the winner of the 2020 Belmont Stakes.

title: China Reveals Key Powers in Hong Kong National-Security Law
summary: Opposition groups and foreign governments including the U.S. have criticized the plan as gravely undercutting the city's promised autonomy from Beijing. HONG KONG-Beijing plans to vest itself with key powers to enforce national security in Hong Kong, proposing a law that would allow the central government to supervise the policing of subversive activities in the protest-racked city and, in some cases, intervene directly.

title: The Dangerous Secrets Our Working-From-Home Photos Reveal
summary: Cybercriminals can glean many clues from scrutinizing shots of home offices and webconferences. As more people work from home during the Covid-19 pandemic, they are sharing photos of their online meetings and remote-working setups-and that's putting their security at risk.

title: The Virus Is Still Winning. Sports May Have to Wait.
summary: The surge of coronavirus cases in key states, and a flood of positive tests for athletes returning to work, could spoil plans for a sports restart.. Hundreds of college football players have tested positive since returning to campus for practice. Major League Baseball and NHL teams closed their facilities after detecting outbreaks. And the entire NBA is relocating to a part of Florida that is rapidly emerging as a hot spot.

title: Gadgets Should Have Expiration Dates
summary: Your internet-connected devices could experience service interruptions or even sudden death due to business deal, tech breakthrough or economic slump. Sammy and Teddy Bear wouldn't stop meowing, and Chris Cillo couldn't figure out why. "My cats are never annoying. They're very chill."

title: Apple's WWDC Has Moved Online. The Tech Industry Is Taking Note.
summary: Pandemic has pushed tech companies to move conferences to the web and rethink engagement and networking. At Apple Inc.'s software conference two years ago, Ken Case peppered peers over breakfasts with questions about their businesses. He said the conversations helped his company avoid mistakes that could have cost thousands of customers and millions of dollars.

title: As Churches Reopen, Catholics Weigh Mixed Blessings of Online Worship
summary: Virtual services boomed during lockdowns, but Pope Francis has reservations. 'This is not the church.'. Since St. Monica Catholic Community in Los Angeles reopened for public worship earlier this month, almost 100 of the faithful at a time have been allowed to attend Sunday Mass, wearing masks and keeping 6 feet away from each other throughout the service.

title: Women's Job Losses From the Pandemic Aren't Good for Recovery
summary: Squeeze on jobs and continued child-care responsibilities are expected to pose setbacks to female employment as businesses start to reopen. Women have lost jobs at a steeper rate than men during the coronavirus pandemic, a factor that is likely to hold back the economic recovery.

title: In the Fashion Industry, Black Activists Push For Deeper Change
summary: Social-media messages and donations aren't enough, say advocates who are pressing for more black professionals in high-level jobs. The fashion industry, which has a fraught history with race, is scrambling to respond to the sweeping social-justice movement with donations and social-media statements. But some black activists within the business say the moves don't go far enough, and are pressing labels to hire and promote more black professionals to key creative and executive positions.

title: Madison Avenue's Latest Diversity Promises Hinge on Accountability
summary: The ad industry has long promised to improve diversity, with little to show. The largest owners of advertising agencies are renewing and expanding their promises to be more diverse and inclusive, an issue the ad industry has pledged to fix for decades.

title: Huawei's 5G Dominance Threatened by U.S. Policy on Chips
summary: Commerce Department ban prevents Chinese tech giant from using many of its own designed components needed for 5G rollout. HONG KONG-When Huawei Technologies Co. was banned last year from buying American parts, the Chinese tech giant had a workaround: make greater use of its own chips.

title: Warehouse Demand Surges as Retailers Reset Supply Chains
summary: A sharp drop that began with coronavirus-triggered lockdowns in March has turned around amid a consumer rush toward e-commerce. Demand for U.S. warehouse space is rebounding as upheaval from the coronavirus pandemic pushes businesses to retool their supply chains.

title: Stimulus Options Create Quandary for Senate GOP
summary: More spending could speed recovery from coronavirus pandemic, but it could also alienate conservative supporters. WASHINGTON-The choice before Senate Republicans pondering the need for additional economic stimulus couldn't be more fraught.

title: Restaurant Reservations, Driving Directions and Other Indicators Wall Street Is Watching
summary: Investors and analysts are tracking a number of unconventional metrics as they try to predict the stock market's trajectory. Traders are no longer just watching economic data to decide what to buy and when.

title: A Showbiz Lawyer Wheels and Deals While He Walks
summary: Resume Subscription. Before the coronavirus pandemic, Darren Trattnerfelt accomplished if he walked 10 miles a week. Now he logs more than 10 miles a day. The Los Angeles-based entertainment lawyer admits the distance sounds daunting. But he breaks up the mileage. "Normally I'd be going to breakfast, lunch and dinner meetings," he says. "Now I do business while I walk."

title: As Pandemic Slows Business, Workers Fret: Is My Job Relevant?
summary: Time for reflection has many questioning their self-worth and the purpose of positions they once found meaningful. Months into a pandemic that brought businesses to a standstill and upended daily routines, many workers are wondering: Does my job matter?

title: Photos of the Week
summary: North Korea blows up liaison office as tensions rise, protesters march nationwide on Juneteenth, U.S. unemployment claims edge lower and more. George Floyd protests "moved our work forward by leaps and bounds," says Black Lives Matter L.A. co-founder Melina Abdullah. Behind sudden moves to address law enforcement's treatment of minorities is years of work by a network of activist groups. Read more.

title: The Credit-Card Fees Merchants Hate, Banks Love and Consumers Pay
summary: Growing and largely hidden interchange economy creates 'a giant reverse Robin Hood'. In Silver Spring, a Maryland suburb of Washington, D.C., cash is becoming a rarity as consumers increasingly rely on credit cards, apps and online purchases during the pandemic.

title: Social Distancing on Trains Could Mean Longer Commutes to Manhattan
summary: Problems for employees returning to work include getting to work on time, traffic jams for cars and long waits for elevators. For New York City workers, the commute is a big obstacle to returning to the office. Unlike other, more car-dependent cities, a large share of Manhattan office workers take the bus or subway to work. Crowded subway cars raise the risk of infection, but keeping a distance between commuters could make it much harder to get to work on time. In a recent study, real-estate services firm Savills Inc. found that if 50% fewer people are allowed to board the L train, one of the city's most used subway lines, at rush hour, the average commuter faces a delay of 15 to 18 minutes if all commuters return to work.

title: Companies Are Paying a Lot More to Insure Their Directors and Officers
summary: Driving the increases in rates is the rise in shareholder litigation, both in the number of cases and size of jury awards and settlements. Many companies in the U.S. and Australia are paying steeply higher rates for insurance that covers costs for directors and top executives when they or the company are sued.

title: Vaccine Efforts Focus on Vulnerable Group: Older Adults
summary: Researchers explore different ways to ensure coronavirus shots in development protect elderly. Health experts are worried about whether coronavirus vaccines under development will adequately protect the elderly, sparking efforts to make sure there are shots that can help the vulnerable group.

title: New Yorkers Now Can Return to the Office. Most Are Staying Away.
summary: Real-estate brokers and landlords expect only 10% to 20% of Manhattan's office workers will return on Monday.

title: Companies Battle Cybersecurity Risks of Having More Remote Workers
summary: Hackers see working-from-home employees as weak points into company networks. Here's what businesses are doing to shore up their defenses.. Companies that moved to remote work because of the coronavirus now face another long-term question mark: security.

title: American Addiction Centers Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Publicly traded parent AAC Holdings and more than three dozen affiliates seek chapter 11 protection. AAC Holdings Inc., the publicly traded owner and operator of substance-abuse treatment company American Addiction Centers Inc., filed for bankruptcy protection Saturday.

title: Florida Reports Another Record High of Daily Covid-19 Cases
summary: India posts new daily record of cases, as the government eases restrictions. Florida: The state, which broadly began the second phase of its reopening June 5, including movie theaters, bars and other entertainment venues, hit another record number of daily cases, according to data released by its health department Saturday morning. Florida's total cases have climbed to more than 93,000, and more than 3,100 people have died. The share of people testing positive has also climbed, to about 10% this week from about half that the week prior. Gov. Ron DeSantis said at a press conference that confirmed positive cases were increasingly concentrated among younger people, who were less likely to have severe symptoms, and that the state had ample hospital beds to accommodate a higher number of infections.

title: At Trump Tulsa Rally, Emotions Run High
summary: Thousands of supporters and protesters gathered on Saturday in anticipation of President Trump's Tulsa, Okla., rally, his first since the coronavirus took hold in the U.S.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump Fires Manhattan U.S. Attorney
summary: Geoffrey Berman says he will leave office immediately, ending daylong standoff. Manhattan U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman will leave office immediately, he said Saturday evening, hours after Attorney General William Barr said he had asked President Trump to fire him.
